items.title: Wrong release?
items.body:
The release of [0.2.6](https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/releases/tag/0.2.6) should include the [commit](https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/commit/37e38eb0656b42349761f697f05e4d11562a2fb1) which replace "pathlib" with "pathlib2", but the released 0.2.6 does not include this commit, see "setup.py" in the release:
```
......
    install_requires=[
        "jsonschema<3",
        "PyYAML>=3.13",
        "six",
        'pathlib;python_version=="2.7"',
    ],
......
```
Same error with #65

items.title: Support reading from STDIN
items.body:
It would be nice if the executable were able to read from STDIN instead of from a file. The default convention for this in *nix is to read from STDIN if `-` is specified as the filename. This is convenient when validating an automatically generated OpenAPI spec, because then it does not need to be saved as a file first.

I think this "issue" can receive the `kind:enhancement` tag.

items.title: Bad python3.4+ wheel
items.body:
The wheels published to pypi for python3 contain bad metadata.

https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/09/57/d66ecb940d656f6762efa0216317d3b97b7dd0e2b2e07c671c7b1de5a2dc/openapi_spec_validator-0.2.6-py3-none-any.whl

Specifically

```Requires-Dist: pathlib```

Should only be present for python < 3.4.

items.title: Partial validation
items.body:
Hi!
I'm wondering if it is possible to validate only a schema or a path definition only (versus the whole schema)
Is it?

items.title: update the dependency
items.body: please update jsonschema to v3 in requirements, or it will fail with dependency check when I use frameworks such as connexion

items.title: Does not work with PyTest
items.body:
See this ticket in PyTest bug tracker: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/4882 .

I don't know how you built the distributable package, but it looks like this:

```
Metadata-Version: 2.0
Name: openapi-spec-validator
Version: 0.2.6
Summary: UNKNOWN
Home-page: https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator
Author: Artur Maciag
Author-email: maciag.artur@gmail.com
License: Apache License, Version 2.0
Platform: UNKNOWN
Classifier: Development Status :: 4 - Beta
Classifier: Intended Audience :: Developers
Classifier: Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules
Classifier: Operating System :: OS Independent
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 2.7
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 3.5
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 3.6
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 3.7
Requires-Dist: jsonschema (<3)
Requires-Dist: PyYAML (>=3.13)
Requires-Dist: six
Requires-Dist: pathlib

# OpenAPI Spec validator
...
```

So, it installs `pathlib` regardless of what version of Python is used (interestingly, it works differently with different versions of Python / setuptools), but Python 7.1 `setuptools` 40.6.2 don't work with your library (downloaded from pypi).

items.title: Timeouts reading large description files
items.body:
Reading a large OpenAPI YAML file that refers to many subcomponent $ref references on the web, I am encountering "timed out" messages partway through pulling in the description.

1) Is this timeout controllable?

2) Can OpenAPI input be provided through a URL rather than just by a local starting YAML file?

items.title: Using unmaintained version of pathlib package
items.body:
The `install_requires` in `setup.py` currently includes a dependency on [pathlib](https://pypi.org/project/pathlib/) package: https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/blob/aab9b2c088132c786d090dcb3e1e2779fc1b7fb6/setup.py#L74

According to its description, this package is currently unmaintained and the authors recommend to consider using the [pathlib2](https://pypi.org/project/pathlib2/) package instead.

Also, the environment marker `python_version=="2.7"` does not seem to work. From my experience, the `pathlib` package was installed as a dependency even on Python 3.7.

items.title: AttributeError: module 'jsonschema._validators' has no attribute 'properties_draft4'
items.body:
This happens with openapi-spec-validator==0.2.5 and jsonschema==3.0.0

```
  File "/data/web/****/api/v2/models.py", line 7, in <module>
    from openapi_spec_validator import validate_spec
  File "/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openapi_spec_validator/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from openapi_spec_validator.factories import JSONSpecValidatorFactory
  File "/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openapi_spec_validator/factories.py", line 5, in <module>
    from openapi_spec_validator.generators import (
  File "/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openapi_spec_validator/generators.py", line 12, in <module>
    class SpecValidatorsGeneratorFactory:
  File "/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openapi_spec_validator/generators.py", line 19, in SpecValidatorsGeneratorFactory
    'properties': _validators.properties_draft4,
AttributeError: module 'jsonschema._validators' has no attribute 'properties_draft4'
```

items.title: PyYAML dependency does not allow any non-beta versions
items.body:
In version `0.2.5` the `PyYAML` dependency was changed to `PyYAML>=4.2b1`. Since the latest non-beta version of `PyYAML` is `3.13`, this means that dependency resolution fails if you do not allow beta packages.

Was this intentional? Looking at https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/193, the release story for `PyYAML` is a bit of a mess, but my understanding is that `3.13` was released to add Python 3.7 compatibility and the "should the `load` function be safe by default" issue will be resolved in an upcoming version 5.

items.title: Maximum & minimum does not work at parameters
items.body:
### Description

```
limit:
  description: The number of items to return
  in: query
  name: limit
  required: true
  schema:
    type: integer
    minimum: 1
    maximum: 1000

```
### Expected behaviour

Numbers above and below 1 and 1000 must to decline by server

### Actual behaviour

They are being accepted

### Steps to reproduce

Just try to validate integer by `maximum` and `minimum` at parameters

### Additional info:

Output of the commands:

- `Python 3.7.2`
- `Version: 2018.0.dev1`

items.title: jsonschema 3.0+ support
items.body:
Hi, the jsonschema has been updated to [3.0+](https://github.com/Julian/jsonschema/releases), and maybe has some break changes:
```shell
.eggs/openapi_spec_validator-0.2.4-py3.6.egg/openapi_spec_validator/__init__.py:7: in <module>
    from openapi_spec_validator.factories import JSONSpecValidatorFactory
.eggs/openapi_spec_validator-0.2.4-py3.6.egg/openapi_spec_validator/factories.py:5: in <module>
    from openapi_spec_validator.generators import (
.eggs/openapi_spec_validator-0.2.4-py3.6.egg/openapi_spec_validator/generators.py:12: in <module>
    class SpecValidatorsGeneratorFactory:
.eggs/openapi_spec_validator-0.2.4-py3.6.egg/openapi_spec_validator/generators.py:19: in SpecValidatorsGeneratorFactory
    'properties': _validators.properties_draft4,
E   AttributeError: module 'jsonschema._validators' has no attribute 'properties_draft4'
```

items.title: Unable to find path
items.body:
No matter what path I use, I always get this error:

`<urlopen error [WinError 3] The system cannot find the path specified: ''>`

The path can be either absolute to a file, or to the http://localhost/openapi.json

As you can see in the error, despite calling it with:
`openapi-spec-validator http://localhost/openjson.api`
the error is implying that I'm not providing any path at all.

for the filepath, I've tried both forward and back slashes:
`c:\my_path\openapi.json`
and
`c:/my_path/openapi.sjon`

Python 3.6, installed via pip

items.title: defaults not checked in swagger 2.0
items.body:
The defaults block within a parameter is not type checked in swagger 2.0 specs.
version: `0.2.3`
python version: `3.6.5`
```
(venv) ✔ ~/stash/connexion/tests/fixtures/bad_specs > cat swagger.yaml 
swagger: "2.0"

info:
  title: "{{title}}"
  version: "1.0"

basePath: /v1.0

paths:
  /welcome:
    get:
      operationId: fakeapi.foo_bar.search
      parameters:
        # The default below validates, but is obviously the wrong type
        - name: foo
          in: query
          type: integer
          default: somestring   # wrong type!!
      responses:
        200:
          description: search
          schema:
            type: object
(venv) ✔ ~/stash/connexion/tests/fixtures/bad_specs > openapi-spec-validator --schema 2.0 swagger.yaml 
OK
(venv) ✔ ~/stash/connexion/tests/fixtures/bad_specs > python
Python 3.6.5 (default, Apr  1 2018, 05:46:30) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import openapi_spec_validator
>>> openapi_spec_validator.__version__
'0.2.3'
```

items.title: Valid response definition shows validation error
items.body:
When using a valid OpenAPI spec (validated also by the swagger editor) an error is returned on the responses validation.

```
$ python -m openapi_spec_validator ~/development/draft/api.yaml
{'description': 'Changed with success.', 'content': {'application/json': {'schema': {'$ref': '#/components/responses/GenericSuccess', 'x-scope': ['file:///development/draft/api.yaml']}}}} is not valid under any of the given schemas

Failed validating 'oneOf' in schema['properties']['paths']['patternProperties']['^/']['properties']['post']['properties']['responses']['patternProperties']['^([0-9X]{3})$']:
    {'oneOf': [{'$ref': '#/definitions/response'},
               {'$ref': '#/definitions/reference'}]}

On instance['paths']['/pets/{id}/comments']['post']['responses']['200']:
    {'content': {'application/json': {'schema': {'$ref': '#/components/responses/GenericSuccess',
                                                 'x-scope': ['file:///development/draft/api.yaml']}}},
     'description': 'Changed with success.'}
```

The spec looks like:
```yaml
...
    put:
      summary: Comments.
      operationId: api.change
      requestBody:
        description: Something.
        required: true
        content:
          applicaton/json:
            schema:
              $ref: '#/components/schemas/CChange'
      responses:
        "200":
          description: Changed with success.
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/responses/GenericSuccess'
...
```

This should not throw an exception. Because the API spec is valid as of https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.0.md#responseObject Unless I'm missing something here.

items.title: defaults aren't validated
items.body:
expected behavior:
a schema like this:
```
..
  parameters:
   - name: number
     schema:
       type: integer
       default: "bad_default"
```
should error because the default is the wrong type.

(behavior also recently added to https://github.com/Yelp/swagger_spec_validator)

items.title: Question: PyYAML vs pyaml dependency
items.body:
There are two packages on PyPI whose package name differs by one character:

- [`PyYAML`](https://pypi.org/project/PyYAML/): This is the core YAML parser (what I would expect to be installed)
- [`pyaml`](https://pypi.org/project/pyaml/): This is "pretty yaml", which is built on top of PyYAML

`pyaml` ("pretty yaml") is the library installed in both [setup.py](https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/blob/70f5731d80da88405df6945fcdd0cb4ee0612698/setup.py#L72) and in the [requirements.txt](https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/blob/70f5731d80da88405df6945fcdd0cb4ee0612698/requirements.txt#L2)). Is `pyaml` actually needed/used or should that be switched to just install `PyYAML`?

items.title: OpenAPI 3.0 spec not parsing required properly
items.body:
I have a spec with components that look like this: 

components:
  schemas:
    Credit:
      type: object
      properties:
        clientId:
          type: string
    CreditCreate:
      allOf:
        - $ref: '#/components/schemas/Credit'
        - required:
          - clientId
I'm doing it like this because there are about 30 fields in credit, and 10 in required. All the fields in required are present in the linked object (or objects if I'm linking more than one). This is rejected by the code in validators.py inside SchemaValidator. iter_errors calls itself recursively on each piece of the allOf, but this doesn't let me reuse another object and simply add some fields as required. I worked around it for now by telling iter_errors to check that the properties field contains something before erroring, but I'm not sure that it is the correct fix. This behavior is supported in the swagger editor and in redoc, so I'm working off the assumption that it should be valid 3.0 syntax.

items.title: schema 2.0 return expected string or buffer
items.body:
Without specifying `--schema 2.0` the file is read, but a parsing error occurs (see bottom), specifying 2.0 returns `expected string or buffer`. This should be a 2.0 valid file, in use with connexxion.

Is this due to an error in parsing the yaml, or is something not right when using this parameter?

```
openapi-spec-validator --schema 2.0 cms/cms/openapi/cms.yaml
expected string or buffer
```

```
'openapi' is a required property

Failed validating 'required' in schema:
```

items.title: unit tests pull v2 spec from web
items.body:
description
==
The swagger2 spec in `openapi_spec_validator/resources/schemas/v2.0/schema.json` contains the line

```
"id": "http://swagger.io/v2/schema.json#",
```

When this schema is opened by the jsonschema RefResolver, it doesn't match the provided on-disk schema_url (`file:///my/repo/path/openapi-spec-validator/openapi_spec_validator/resources/schemas/v2.0/schema.json`) and so tries to resolve the reference by fetching `"http://swagger.io/v2/schema.json#` from the web.

This does not occur on the v3.0.x schema because it does not have an `id` field.

steps to reproduce:
==
add `127.0.0.1    swagger.io` to your `/etc/hosts` file
run `pytest`

the tests fail, as they are unable to resolve `http://swagger.io/v2/schema.json#`

potential fixes:
===
1. remove `id` field from v2.0 schema
https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/compare/master...dtkav:local_swagger2

2. if a schema has an `id`, accept that over the provided schema url (the on-disk location)
https://github.com/p1c2u/openapi-spec-validator/compare/master...dtkav:no_web_fetch

items.title: openapi-spec-validator leaks jsonschema exceptions
items.body:
The openapi-spec-validator leaks `jsonschema.ValidationError` exceptions.
for example:
```
from openapi_spec_validator import validate_spec
validate_spec("")  # raises jsonschema.ValidationError
```
One thing you could do is wrap these exceptions with `raise from` in python3 like:
```
raise OpenAPIValidationError("JSONSchema Error") from e
```
There's some points on https://julien.danjou.info/python-exceptions-guide/#wrappingexceptions

Let me know what you think!

items.title: v2.0 schema is missing
items.body:
I stumbled on the following error when trying to run validate_spec_url :
`FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'C:\\(...)\\Python36-32\\lib\\site-packages\\openapi_spec_validator\\resources\\schemas\\v2.0\\schema.json'`

I am no Python package expert but I believe it is missing from setup.py.

items.title: Allow $ref to use `../`  for reference to parent directory file
items.body:
Dir structure:
```
├── fileA.yml
├── folderB
│   └── fileB.yml
```

From `fileB.yml` the validator does not permit usage of  `$ref: ../fileA.yml#/items/id` . 
It works fine without the `../` in the beginning though. 

This would allow the openapi spec v3 files to be rendered on the browser using swagger-ui tool.

items.title: Q: how to validate spec files?
items.body:
I see your examples in the README.md, but I'm writing a spec file from scratch in YAML and want to valid that what I'm writing is correct. All your examples provide a `spec_dict` value but no information on what it is. As it stands, the examples look more like an input validator for HTTP calls by a client versus  validating the spec data itself. Could you please clarify:
- how to validate the spec file being written
- what `spec_dict` is

Thanks!
